title: Our Relationship Story
description: Reflect on your journey together and the narrative of your love.

questions.text: How would I describe the story of how we met?
choices: A chance encounter turned into destiny
We grew from friends into something more
There was an instant connection
It took time, but something special developed

therapeutic.rationale: Gottman's research shows that how couples tell their origin story predicts relationship success. Destiny-framers see fate; friends-to-more framers value foundation; instant-connection framers emphasize chemistry; slow-developers appreciate patience; unexpected-beginning framers find meaning in surprise. The story we tell about our beginning shapes how we understand our relationship.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different origin-story framings show you each interpret your beginning differently. Both perspectives are true—share how you see your story.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared origin-story framing means you tell the same story about your beginning. This shared narrative strengthens your couple identity.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you tell the story of how you met? What do you emphasize? How does your partner tell it differently?

questions.text: What chapter of our relationship has been most meaningful?
choices: The exciting beginning when everything was new
When we went through something hard together
A period of deep growth and change
Ordinary times when we felt most ourselves

therapeutic.rationale: Which chapter we find most meaningful reveals what we value in relationships. Beginning-lovers value excitement and discovery; hardship-survivors value resilience and bonding; growth-celebrators value evolution; ordinary-moment lovers value presence; present-appreciators value current reality. Each perspective highlights different relationship strengths.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different meaningful chapters reveal different valued experiences. Your partner may treasure a chapter you barely remember as significant. Share why these times mattered.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared meaningful chapters create aligned relationship narratives. You both see the same period as defining. This is a touchstone of your story.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What period of your relationship has been most meaningful? Why? Have you shared this perspective with your partner?

questions.text: What has been our greatest challenge?
choices: Learning to communicate effectively
Getting through a difficult life circumstance
Growing individually while staying close
Building trust or working through hurt

therapeutic.rationale: Acknowledging challenges creates honest narrative. Communication challenges are most common; different needs require ongoing negotiation; life circumstances test resilience; individual-versus-couple balance requires calibration; trust challenges demand repair. Couples who can name their challenges without blame demonstrate relationship maturity.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different perceived challenges show you've experienced different struggle areas. Both perspectives are valid—understanding how your partner sees your challenges deepens mutual awareness.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared challenge recognition means you're aligned on what's been hard. This shared understanding creates partnership in overcoming.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What has been the biggest challenge in your relationship? How did you navigate it? What did you learn?

questions.text: If I told someone what makes our relationship work, I'd say...
choices: How well we communicate
The deep respect we have for each other
Our ability to laugh together
The commitment we share

therapeutic.rationale: How we explain our relationship's success reveals perceived strengths. Communication highlights skill; respect highlights values; laughter highlights joy; commitment highlights devotion; balance highlights complementarity. These explanations become self-fulfilling—what we believe makes us work, we tend to maintain.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different success explanations show you each see different strengths. Both are probably true—share what you think makes you work.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared success explanation means you're aligned on your core strength. Protect and nurture this quality—it's your foundation.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you think makes your relationship work? Would your partner agree? What would be lost if this quality disappeared?

questions.text: What do I want the rest of our story to be about?
choices: Deepening our connection and intimacy
Building adventures and memories together
Creating stability and lasting security
Growing as individuals while staying united

therapeutic.rationale: Future story aspirations reveal what we want love to mean going forward. Deepening-seekers want more intimacy; adventure-builders want experience; stability-seekers want security; growth-seekers want development; together-facers want partnership. Sharing these aspirations helps couples write their future chapter together.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different future-story visions may need integration—but usually can coexist. Adventure and stability aren't opposites. Talk about how your visions can merge.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared future-story vision means you're writing the same next chapter. You're aligned on what you want your love to become.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you want the rest of your relationship story to be about? What would make that story possible? What could threaten it?
